Scale Insects.description: Small, armored or soft-bodied sap-sucking insects that infest leaves and twigs. They cause yellowing, defoliation, and premature fruit drop by extracting plant nutrients.
symptoms: Small brown or grey bumps on stems and leaves
Yellowing and wilting of infested leaves
Loss of plant vigor and stunted growth

favorable_conditions.notes: Thrive in dry conditions with moderate temperatures

Scale Insects.economic_impact: Moderate to High - can cause 20-35% yield loss if uncontrolled

treatments.name: Buprofezin 25% SC
treatments.application: Foliar spray targeting infested twigs and leaves
treatments.precautions: Highly effective against juvenile stages, less on adults

treatments.name: Spirotetramat 150 OD
treatments.precautions: Works through plant sap, avoid rain within 2 hours

treatments.name: Horticultural Oil (Paraffinic)
treatments.application: Thorough coverage spray during cooler hours
treatments.precautions: Spray in early morning or late evening, avoid high temperatures

treatments.name: Chilocorus nigritus (Predatory Beetle)
treatments.frequency: One time release, beetles reproduce naturally
treatments.precautions: Avoid chemical sprays for 30 days after release

preventive_measures: Prune heavily infested branches and destroy
Maintain proper plant spacing for air circulation
Apply sticky bands on trunks to trap crawlers
Apply dormant oil spray during winter

White Flies.description: Tiny white-winged insects that feed on plant sap and secrete honeydew. Whitefly nymphs are particularly damaging as they extract nutrients, causing leaf yellowing and reduced photosynthesis.
symptoms: Clouds of small white flies when plant is disturbed
White nymphs on undersides of leaves
Sticky honeydew on leaves and fruits
Black sooty mold growth on honeydew

favorable_conditions.notes: Population explodes during hot dry weather

White Flies.lifecycle: 25-30 days at optimal temperature, multiple overlapping generations
White Flies.economic_impact: Moderate - can cause 15-30% yield reduction, indirect damage through sooty mold

treatments.name: Diafenthiuron 50% WP
treatments.application: Spray on underside of leaves where nymphs feed
treatments.precautions: Highly toxic to beneficial insects, use selectively

treatments.name: Pyriproxyfen 10% EC
treatments.application: IGR (Insect Growth Regulator), disrupts nymph development
treatments.precautions: Works on immature stages, combine with adult control

treatments.name: Neem Oil + Soap Solution
treatments.precautions: Safe for organic farming, spray during cooler hours

treatments.name: Encarsia formosa (Parasitic Wasp)
treatments.application: Release when whitefly population is detected
treatments.precautions: Avoid insecticides 30 days before and after release

preventive_measures: Install yellow sticky traps for monitoring and mass trapping
Use reflective mulches to repel whiteflies
Maintain proper irrigation to avoid water stress

monitoring.inspection_frequency: Twice weekly during hot dry periods
monitoring.threshold: Spray when 5 adults per trap or 3-5 nymphs per leaf

Mealy Bug.description: Small, soft-bodied insects covered with white waxy secretion. Major pest of custard apple causing leaf curl, stunted growth, and fruit drop.
symptoms: White cottony masses on stems, leaves, and fruits
Honeydew secretion leading to sooty mold

treatments.name: Imidacloprid 17.8% SL
treatments.precautions: Avoid during flowering stage, wear protective equipment

treatments.name: Thiamethoxam 25% WG
treatments.precautions: Do not mix with alkaline chemicals

treatments.name: Neem Oil 1500 ppm
treatments.application: Spray thoroughly on all plant parts
treatments.precautions: Safe for organic farming, spray in evening

treatments.name: Cryptolaemus montrouzieri (Ladybird beetle)
treatments.precautions: Avoid chemical sprays for 2 weeks after release

preventive_measures: Remove and destroy heavily infested plant parts
integrated_management: Spray neem oil solution (5ml/L) at 15-day intervals

Athracnose.description: Major fungal disease affecting fruits, leaves, and flowers of custard apple. Causes significant post-harvest losses.
symptoms: Sunken lesions with pinkish spore masses
Athracnose.pathogen_lifecycle: Survives on plant debris, spreads through rain splash and wind
Athracnose.economic_impact: Very High - can cause 50-70% post-harvest loss

treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
treatments.precautions: Wear mask and gloves, avoid spray drift

treatments.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
treatments.precautions: May cause phytotoxicity on young leaves

treatments.name: Carbendazim 50% WP
treatments.precautions: Rotate with other fungicides to avoid resistance

treatments.name: Trichoderma viride
treatments.precautions: Store in cool place, use within expiry

preventive_measures: Remove and destroy infected fruits and leaves
integrated_management: Apply Trichoderma to soil and foliage
Alternate with Carbendazim during disease pressure
Post-harvest treatment with hot water (52째C for 5 min)

Diplodia Rot.description: Post-harvest fungal disease causing significant fruit rot during storage and transport.
symptoms: Brown to black discoloration of fruit
Soft, watery rot starting from stem end
Diplodia Rot.pathogen_lifecycle: Enters through wounds, stem ends, or natural openings

treatments.name: Thiophanate Methyl 70% WP
treatments.application: Spray on fruits 2 weeks before harvest
treatments.precautions: Avoid mixing with copper-based fungicides

treatments.name: Hot Water Treatment
treatments.precautions: Maintain exact temperature, cool fruits gradually

treatments.name: Carbendazim 12% + Mancozeb 63% WP
treatments.precautions: Use before fruit maturity

preventive_measures: Store fruits in cool (8-10째C), dry conditions
integrated_management: Hot water treatment immediately after harvest
Regular inspection and removal of infected fruits

Leaf spot on fruit.description: Fungal disease causing spots on fruits and leaves, reducing fruit quality and marketability.
symptoms: Small circular to irregular spots on fruits
Spots may coalesce causing large lesions
Premature fruit drop in severe cases
Leaf spot on fruit.pathogen_lifecycle: Spreads through wind and rain splash, survives on plant debris

treatments.name: Carbendazim 50% WP
treatments.precautions: Rotate with other fungicide groups

treatments.name: Propiconazole 25% EC
treatments.precautions: Avoid during hot weather

treatments.name: Copper Hydroxide 77% WP
treatments.precautions: May stain fruits

integrated_management: Apply Carbendazim at fruit set stage
Apply balanced nutrition (NPK based on soil test)

Leaf spot on Leaves.description: Foliar disease affecting leaf health and photosynthetic capacity of custard apple plants.
symptoms: Circular to angular spots on leaves
Leaf spot on Leaves.pathogen_lifecycle: Survives on fallen leaves, spreads through water splash
Leaf spot on Leaves.economic_impact: Medium - indirect impact on fruit quality and yield

treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
treatments.precautions: Complete coverage essential

treatments.name: Tebuconazole 25.9% EC
treatments.precautions: Use during early infection stage

treatments.name: Bordeaux Mixture (1%)
treatments.precautions: Prepare fresh solution, may cause phytotoxicity

integrated_management: Apply micronutrients to improve plant health
Maintain optimal plant vigor through proper nutrition

Blank Canker.description: Stem and branch canker disease causing dieback and reducing plant productivity.
symptoms: Sunken lesions on stems and branches
Blank Canker.pathogen_lifecycle: Enters through wounds, spreads through infected pruning tools
Blank Canker.economic_impact: High - long-term impact on plant health and productivity

treatments.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
treatments.precautions: Apply after pruning to prevent infection

treatments.name: Bordeaux Paste
treatments.application: Apply on pruned surfaces and cankers
treatments.precautions: Remove diseased tissue before application

treatments.name: Thiophanate Methyl 70% WP
treatments.precautions: Prune infected branches before treatment

preventive_measures: Maintain plant vigor through proper nutrition
integrated_management: Prune infected branches 15-20 cm below symptoms
Apply Bordeaux paste on cut surfaces
Sanitize pruning tools with 10% bleach solution

Physical Damage (Fruit Rubbing).description: Black spots or abrasions caused by fruits rubbing against branches or other fruits due to wind or overcrowding. Often mistaken for disease.
symptoms: Black or brown scuff marks on fruit surface
Occurs on exposed side or contact points
Physical Damage (Fruit Rubbing).economic_impact: Low - Cosmetic damage only, but reduces market value

June (Pre-Monsoon).Micronutrients: Apply Zinc Sulphate and Ferrous Sulphate if soil deficient

Phule Purandar.description: A high-yielding variety of Custard Apple developed by MPKV, Rahuri. Known for less seeds and more pulp.
specific_care: Requires proper thinning to prevent fruit rubbing
Windbreaks recommended to reduce rubbing damage

general_recommendations.monitoring: Inspect plants weekly during growing season, twice weekly during monsoon
general_recommendations.record_keeping: Maintain records of pest/disease occurrences, weather conditions, and treatments applied
general_recommendations.resistance_management: Rotate fungicides with different modes of action to prevent resistance
general_recommendations.organic_options: Neem-based products, Trichoderma, and cultural practices for organic farming
general_recommendations.safety: Always wear protective equipment, follow label instructions, observe pre-harvest intervals
